Will Formula One's rule changes affect the drama?

05/01/2011

Luke Gardener assesses whether Formula One's new rule changes, coming in next season, will impinge on the excitement of the sport (Thumbnail credit Will the rule changes allow Vettel to remain number one next year? Image: Silverstone Circuits Limited via Flickr Creative Commons)

Image by

By undefined undefined

2010 was an incredible season for Formula One and with a championship fight which involved five contenders for so much of the season, many are calling it the greatest season in the history of the sport. However, not everything was as good as the sports governing body, the FIA had hoped it would be. There were still problems with overtaking, dangerous driving and the team orders fiasco which was generated by Ferrari in Germany midway through the season. With the season being so exciting despite these significant problems, it poses the question; if Formula One solves these problems could the sport be an even greater spectacle to an even greater audience? In the eyes of many Formula One drivers and teams it is simply unrealistic to eradicate these problems, but FIA President, Jean Todt, is determined to make progress and has outlined a number of new rulings for the coming 2011 season and ultimately for Formula One to change drastically by the 2013 season. The changes which are to be implemented immediately in the new season are extremely significant. Team orders are to once again be allowed after the controversial Hockenheim incident which involved Felipe Massa handing Fernando Alonso a win which almost resulted in the Spaniard winning his third World Drivers Championship. With Ferrari receiving a modest fine for their actions it seemed this was always going to be changed but it will no doubt remain a controversial ruling in the next season, when incidents such as these become perfectly fine. For the watching audience that may not be F1 fanatics or fully understand the sport they will see this as unsporting and unfair. Even for someone like me, an avid Formula One follower, when you see one car blatantly hand a victory to another driver it makes the sport seem shallow and superficial and questions whether the most talented drivers gain the reward they deserve. Another FIA measure which has been taken for the coming season is a far harsher system when it comes to punishing bad or dangerous driving. Drivers can no longer assume that they will only receive drive through penalties as stewards are being given greater power. They will now be able to exclude drivers from a race and also suspend them from competing in the next Grand Prix as well. It remains to be seen whether these punishments are actually used in 2011 but I would argue that there have been instances in the past where they could have been applied. The scenario which comes to mind is the infamous Michael Schumacher and Rubens Barrichello incident on the pit straight in Hungary of last season where Schumacher so nearly put his former Ferrari teammate into the barrier which could have ended in serious injury or ultimately death. In these circumstances I believe it would have been an appropriate action to exclude Schumacher from the race and perhaps even the next race as well. Stewards will be able to make it clear to drivers they will be unable to get away with dangerous driving with these new regulations. The two biggest changes when it comes to the cars themselves are the re-introduction of KERS (Kinetic Energy Recovery System) and adjustable rear wings becoming available for the first time. These changes are aimed at both improving overtaking opportunity whilst still giving the driver enough of a challenge, something the FIA is trying to balance. The wings will be operated by the drivers themselves but will be activated electronically when they are within a second of the car in front. These gaps will be monitored by the FIA in hope that they can introduce changes and improvements after analysing how effective the rear wings become. These calculations are made more complicated by KERS as the system stores energy that is wasted during braking and can be re-used during acceleration to give a power boost for seven seconds. The FIA have admitted that there will be problems with the inclusion of both these changes but hope to have fully rectified any adverse effects the systems have on each other by 2013 and ultimately improve the major problem which remains in the sport, overtaking. The 2013 season will be vitally important to Formula One as this is the season they are aiming to embrace sustainability. A new, greener engine has already been announced which aims to improve efficiency combined with KERS and fuel restrictions by up to 35%. This engine change is remarkable as there were a lot of teams arguing that the engines would affect the sport in a negative way but the FIA seem to have won the argument and convinced teams and drivers that a more sustainable Formula One is the only way forward. As well as the engine changes, there have been whole new set of technical regulations proposed for the season. The major changes proposed for 2013 are to slow down the cars but making it more of a challenge for drivers with smaller wings. There will be a major reduction in the downforce created by the car, the underfloor of the car to be shaped for the first time since the 1982 season to generate downforce along with wings and drivers will be able to spend up to 20% less time on the throttle per lap. These changes will all lead to better overtaking and will challenge the drivers to levels they have never experienced. It will be incredibly interesting to see if any of these changes have an adverse effect on any of the current drivers or whether they will be able to manage the changes and show that they truly are the best drivers on the planet. There is no doubt that Formula One is trying to change to become a more sustainable sport, but can the excitement it generated in the 2010 season be replicated after these changes are made?
